arch:property.oc:show_val: West of center in North Wall (Locus 6).
0.66 m north south-by-2.75 m east west.

A semi-circular (apsidal) architectural feature that bows toward the north. It is bonded to the North Wall (Locus 6), and is located west of the midpoint for the north wall. Two types of construction are evident in the two-row wall. The interior (south) face is constructed of nicely dressed or hewn sandstone ashlars, which are slightly curved to accommodate the apsidal shape. The exterior (north) face is built using a combination of hewn and dressed sandstone blocks as well, but given that the entire face was not exposed, it can not be determined if the stones used were also intentionally-shaped to allow for the curvature. The stones for both rows were laid in a header and stretcher arrangement using wet-mortar. The wall remains sturdy, but at least one repair was undertaken in antiquity, when a missing curved ashlar from the interior face was replaced with a block of roughly-shaped mortar (Seq. No. 126256).

Phase VI: Late Nabataean pre-CE 106 minor collapses and repairs. At this time the northwest subterranean channel is damaged and clogged with CE 1st c. pottery. Repairs are made to the Hexagonal Pavement as well as to the East Exedra walls. Bath Complex built.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Petra Great Temple Excavations: Locus 10 (Locus)
